The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan, where farmland transitions into small tourist towns. There are no large shopping malls, no Walmart, Target, or even an Applebee's. You need to drive everywhere you want to go. Nevertheless, I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "town" is embraced by water - the magnificent Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. You can find a beach to dip your toes in wherever you go.

My neighborhood embodies small-town life. The houses aren't cramped together or built from the same cookie-cutter design. They're older homes, some renovated and updated, others maintaining their original character. Most have full basements visible from the street, and many feature classic aluminum siding. The houses in our blocks come in every imaginable color. Most properties have yards with trampolines and play equipment. Some residents maintain gardens and have fenced areas for their pets.

These houses represent Middle America - hardworking people making a living, either raising families or having already raised them. Children play in the streets daily, while people walk their dogs, ride bikes, and rollerblade. Neighbors know each other, and you can easily tell who belongs and who doesn't. You'll see people grilling outdoors and waving, or dog walkers from a few blocks away offering friendly smiles.

The properties are well-maintained, with no leftover autumn leaves, neatly mowed lawns, and trimmed bushes and plants. While it's not the kind of neighborhood that makes you marvel at luxurious homes, it's one that makes you think, "This would be a great place to raise a family." It's peaceful, quiet, and safe - exceptional because it represents what people want: a secure haven at day's end.

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, the health department, and the city recycling center, which serves the whole community. Nearby baseball and softball fields fill the air with the sound of announcers calling games. Our small town airport adds the occasional rumble of small planes taking off and landing. You can walk to the local ice cream shop, and ambitious walkers can reach downtown. My children can bike to the park, just eight blocks away. It truly is a wonderful place to call home.

The area where I live can be characterized as a typical, uniform suburban development. In my neighborhood, the presence of a homeowners association (HOA) is very noticeable. Upon entering, you'll find nothing but meticulously maintained single-family homes, which we can attribute to the HOA's oversight. The front yards share a striking similarity - each featuring a modest patch of manicured lawn, decorative gravel, and relatively short driveways. Small trees dot the landscape occasionally. Every home comes with a two-car garage. Throughout the neighborhood, you'll notice freshly paved concrete roads. Despite housing numerous families, the street infrastructure remains in pristine condition, free from potholes or similar defects.

While most residences are single-story, you'll occasionally encounter two-story homes. Rather than individual mailboxes at each house, we have a centralized mail station at the end of each street, similar to apartment complexes. Residents access their designated mailbox with a key, and there are two larger compartments for package deliveries - another example of the HOA's commitment to uniformity.

Our neighborhood sits at the city's outer edge, creating an interesting blend of suburban and rural elements. This location affords us ample space for various amenities, including multiple gated community pools accessible to all residents. There's an extensive network of walking trails perfect for dog walking or evening strolls. The neighborhood's size itself provides sufficient space for exercise without needing to visit a park.

The community predominantly consists of retirees, with a smaller mix of middle-aged residents and young professionals. It's a secure area where neighbors look out for each other. While our city is surprisingly populous, it maintains a small-town atmosphere. We have access to most modern conveniences, including a modestly sized but functional mall. Most destinations require about 15 minutes of driving, but once there, you'll find a wide variety of shopping options - from upscale organic grocery stores to budget-friendly outlets with minimal staffing to keep prices low.

In summary, our neighborhood offers a safe, well-maintained, and typical suburban environment, enhanced by amenities like pools and walking trails. While not immediately adjacent to shopping areas, a short drive provides access to virtually any major retail chain you might need.

The first time I heard about my place was through a podcast about missing persons. It was rather unexpected. Nearly every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars monthly. I had never heard this story before, and neither had any of my friends. Perhaps it's the daily struggle. Some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Everything is expensive, but over the years we've learned to live frugally. You grow accustomed to the musty scent of flea market toys and mothballed clothing. Your sense of smell dulls in adulthood. You might take up smoking, or perhaps you just become desensitized to how things are. But the flea market atmosphere is always present. The scent of adulthood is dusty magazines piled on an unused piano. It seeps into the leather and stays even after washing. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting from the far end, you can visit two charitable thrift shops, a library, a rare bookstore, and a curiosity shop. Downtown is crowded, with cars and people filling the streets each morning, yet the thrift stores remain oddly quiet. No matter how much life flows past outside, inside maintains its silence. It's a perfect place to while away an afternoon. Each year brings more people and vehicles. They call it a developing city. Housing one of the largest online retail and delivery companies, it's still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone focuses on their own objectives, and nobody demands much from you. You can remain solitary, quiet, and self-sufficient, and others will respect your space. Unlike the South, where showing concern is a sign of caring, people here don't intrude into others' lives. You can maintain your privacy as long as you wish, while the city ebbs and flows around you like ocean waves. It's a vibrant place to live. Between the pianist next door and two aspiring singers upstairs, there's always something happening. In many ways, we're less a building of strangers and more a community of friends. We unite for our needs, celebrate birthdays, share in grief, and help each other when possible. I feel fortunate to be here. I genuinely like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I make an effort to clean up after myself and share food with them, and they do the same. We exchange mail and greetings. It's pleasant to see them, and I believe they enjoy my company as much as I enjoy theirs. Though I live in an enormous, impersonal modern urban sprawl, it's people like my neighbors who make me feel like I haven't completely derailed my life.

I reside in a small Midwestern town situated just beyond the suburban areas of a major city. My neighborhood, located in the eastern part of town, could be considered the most economically challenged area. Property values are modest, with most homes either rented or owned by people of limited means. Nevertheless, the area maintains its charm and livability. My neighbors are generally warm and welcoming, offering friendly greetings during my walks through the neighborhood. While crime rates are slightly elevated compared to other areas of town, they remain relatively low overall. There have been several violent incidents within blocks of my home over the past decade, including some shootings and one homicide. Our next-door neighbors experienced the tragic loss of their son in a shooting near a local bar last year. Thankfully, our family has been largely untouched by crime, except for occasional items disappearing from our porch when left outside.

The town has been significantly impacted by the opioid crisis affecting much of the United States, with numerous lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, our community offers various resources to address this crisis, including several rehabilitation facilities and Narcan training programs for affected families and their support networks.

Despite these challenges, our town has numerous positive aspects. The elementary school my son attends boasts exceptional staff at all levels. Despite his special needs, he has experienced no bullying thanks to the school's remarkably positive environment, and he thrives there. Our active PTO organizes numerous events throughout the year to enhance family engagement and educational achievement. Given that over 20% of our population lives below the poverty line, all students receive free breakfast and lunch, ensuring no child goes hungry. The school maintains a dignified environment where no family faces discrimination due to financial circumstances, and school-related expenses remain affordable.

The City Council has implemented various improvements to enhance the town's appearance, including road repairs, landscaping, and park renovations. However, these improvements have primarily focused on the town center and western areas, where retail establishments and main traffic routes are located. The eastern section, where I reside, often receives less attention, causing frustration among neighborhood residents.

Overall, I find life here satisfying. The community is welcoming, the educational system is strong, shopping options are sufficient for our needs, and while our home may not have high market value, it provides comfortable and adequate living space. Having lived here for over 16 years, we couldn't imagine calling anywhere else home.

My neighborhood pulses with cultural vitality. Perched on a hill, it's embraced by buildings steeped in history. I reside in a seven-story apartment complex directly opposite the historic theater, and downhill you'll find this charming arcade bar that draws diverse crowds on balmy summer evenings. Particularly during June and July weekends, you'll often spot queues of people waiting to enter. A few blocks uphill lies the city park - surprisingly spacious for this part of town. The park is framed by concrete walls with broad steps built into them. During the harsh winter months, homeless individuals arrange their tents in orderly rows along the sidewalks and wide steps. While snow is rare, the rain is persistent, and the winter's torrential downpours make staying warm a challenge. By clustering their tents together in the city center rather than in the outskirts, they find better warmth and remain within walking distance of the area's only family center, where they can access bathing facilities.

What captivates me about my city isn't just its historical grandeur - the majestic buildings and diverse architecture cascading down the hills toward the ocean. Rather, it's the cultural fabric of its people that truly moves me. Hilltop was once infamous along the West Coast for gang activity. Even thirty years later, stories circulate about federal agents and DEA sweeps through the neighborhood. The community preserves these memories, passing them down through generations, even to newcomers like myself. Despite still being considered one of the city's rougher areas, residents work diligently to maintain their neighborhood. They remain deeply invested in their community's well-being.

Though some warn white people against walking the Hill after dark, I see this caution as an echo of the past, tainted by social prejudices. Perhaps it's because I'm just dark enough to not appear completely "white," or maybe Hilltop accepts me as one of their own - someone equally conscious of the persistent reminders of our nation's struggles with racism, cultural bias, and fear-based assumptions, even in a supposedly progressive urban melting pot.

One thing remains certain: Hilltop is home, regardless of where life takes me. These streets at night invigorate me, where I've encountered people more likely to offer me their jacket than cause harm. It's where laundromat owners have extended their hours so I could charge my phone during rainstorms. It's where, huddled against storefronts on the gloomiest nights, believing myself invisible, strangers have stopped to look me in the eye, offer me five dollars, and remind me of my worth and beauty.

I moved to this neighborhood just as I was about to begin eighth grade. Initially, I struggled to make friends, but I eventually became close with someone who lived two houses down and another boy from my street. Neither of them lives there anymore, but the memories remain. Most of the people who lived here when I first moved in are still here. My neighborhood resembles a typical American suburban area. There are many two-story houses. On weekends or when it's warm, I hear children playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days. I've never had problems with any neighbors. People here leave you alone unless you need help. I've ordered packages online many times and never had one stolen from my porch. I trust my neighbors. There's a park a minute or two from my house. I have many memories there. I used to play basketball, football, and baseball there with other boys from the neighborhood. I also experienced one of my worst memories there when I took an elbow to the nose during football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. These days, I only go there with my cousin's children. They're much younger than me and still enjoy swings, slides, and that sort of thing. Just the thought of going to the park excites them. The park makes me nostalgic for many different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You can find all kinds of food nearby. Within about a mile radius, there are Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays many people use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash to have food delivered. The most popular places are fast-food restaurants, but you can find those near almost any suburban neighborhood. There are also many pizzerias. The stores here have everything you might need. There are several dry cleaners nearby. There's both a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street, as well as a Jewel-Osco supermarket, which is popular in the Midwest. Some stores are multicultural, like an Indian store if you're in the mood to make homemade Indian food or buy ready-made Indian dishes. Overall, I really like my neighborhood. When I read about horror stories others have with their neighbors on social media and in the news, I'm grateful for mine.

I live in a neighborhood close to my college, which is why I really enjoy living there. The area is dominated by apartment buildings, but there are several restaurants and bars that are fun to visit and reasonably priced. One bar was recently renamed - it's a bit pricier, but the quality of service and drinks isn't bad. Most people in the area are friendly. The residents are either college students or lower-income individuals, since the apartments are quite affordable. There are many children around because an elementary school is within walking distance. I don't know my neighbors, and I prefer it that way. They smoke a lot of marijuana, which led management to install an air freshener across from their door - something my boyfriend and I find quite amusing. Most buildings in the area look dated from the outside but may have updated interiors. Further down the street, there are new apartment buildings, but I'm not fond of them due to their poor construction quality. They charge high rent despite being cheaply built, getting away with it due to their proximity to campus. There's an inexpensive restaurant nearby that serves food on paper plates and mostly relies on microwaved meals. Across from it is a gas station with a reportedly poor work environment. The area recently benefited from city funding that provided new sidewalks, landscaping, and road improvements, making it more attractive. My apartment building is surrounded by trees, though some were recently cut down. The area behind my building, on 43rd Street, isn't as well-maintained, with crumbling sidewalks and run-down buildings hidden behind trees. While there's some crime in the area, particularly in certain complexes, I'm generally happy with where I live. It's affordable, convenient, and offers easy access to both the university and public transportation for reaching stores and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes on a cul-de-sac. They're arranged and spaced in such a way that they appear to be single homes. Their distinguishing feature is their uniform yellow paint, white porches, and green metal roofs. Nearly everyone here is friendly with one another, though not without exception. Some evenings, we gather spontaneously at the end of driveways to chat while neighborhood children play with their toys, draw with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It's refreshing to experience this in our modern, technology-driven world - like stepping back in time. We're surrounded by fields and trees, complemented by blue skies and billowing white clouds.

The only drawback? This season brought tornado warnings, and last night, for the first time, we heard actual tornado sirens that sent us seeking shelter. I found myself in my bathtub, clutching my smallest dog, my purse, and some pillows. My larger dog, anxious about the unusual situation, refused to enter the bathroom and stayed in the living room, barking nervously. The neighborhood fell silent except for the sound of large hailstones striking the ground. After the storm, steam rose from the roads due to the dramatic temperature drop - from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As the skies cleared, the sun emerged while it was still raining, creating a double rainbow. I rushed to capture photos for my Facebook friends and family, who were as amazed as I was.

The streets remained quiet for an hour until people returned from wherever they'd taken shelter during the storm. Then life resumed its normal rhythm, with mothers and children outside while dinner cooked. It's such a welcoming neighborhood for someone like me who recently relocated from New Hampshire to North Carolina. I love the local Southern accent. While we all have two-bedroom, two-bath apartments, and the buildings look identical from the outside, the interior layouts vary surprisingly, with some units being quite compact.

I enjoy walking along the large field behind my home and strolling down to the pond, which isn't meant for swimming. I've spotted deer, and mornings bring the deep songs of bullfrogs. Living just forty minutes outside Charlotte is wonderful. Each day begins with roosters crowing from nearby farms, giving it the feel of a small village community. We even have a donkey at a neighboring farm whose evening braying reminds us of his presence. I feel fortunate to have discovered this neighborhood gem.

Having spent about a decade here, I can share my experiences. When I first moved to this neighborhood, I was quite down. The transition from Riverdale to Stockbridge was emotional - I'll admit I shed tears because I missed my old life and loved ones. My parents made this move for our benefit though - my little sister and I would have access to better housing, a superior high school, and what people considered a "better area." As time passed, I adjusted, making both friends and inevitably some adversaries at school. While I never really got close to most neighbors over the years, Mr. Glen, his children, and briefly Dennis, who lived next door, became almost like family to me. I cherish those connections. I fondly remember attending Mr. Glen's remarriage to Ms. Veda - it was a joyous celebration where I even caught the garter (though missed the bouquet!). We danced all evening, and I particularly enjoyed spending time with their daughter Marsharii, whom I haven't seen since but hope is thriving wherever she is. The neighborhood itself is maze-like, though GPS helps me explore more now. I have fond memories of gaming sessions with my friends Kason and Curtis, living life to its fullest. These days, I find peace practicing balance with sticks from Home Depot and training with my wooden bokken sword in the park. While I haven't played tennis or basketball recently, having those courts nearby is comforting. My dad and Mr. Graves taught my best friend and me tennis - it was demanding but enjoyable. This neighborhood has given me countless wonderful memories, and I believe the best is still ahead!

My neighborhood is a picturesque small town. While it's not different from other towns in South Carolina, it plays a significant role in the agricultural sector. Johnston proudly declares itself the Peach Capital of the World on its welcome sign. The area consists mainly of farmland, dominated by peach orchards and cattle pastures. Houses outside the town center are spread far apart; most are two-story structures with either metal roofs to combat the intense summer heat or gray shingles. These homes are typically set back from the road, allowing the front fields to be used for livestock or crops. The town center features a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where all the town's businesses are located. There are three options for quick meals: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; and Gary's, a small burger chain. A pizza place used to operate here but recently closed. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small family pharmacy, is particularly famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. The town's only grocery store, IGA (Independent Grocers Alliance), is small but expensive, leading most residents to do their main shopping at the Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville. Dollar General is the town's busiest store, offering various everyday items and staying busy from opening to closing. A well-respected community member runs Possibilities Furniture & More, a small furniture store that's been around for many years and offers delivery service. Adjacent to it is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, providing pet grooming, daycare, and boarding services. Both the medical clinic and veterinary practice are located outside the main town area, though they're well-equipped to serve Johnston's residents. Johnston Elementary School is the only school in town, with students attending middle and high school in the neighboring town. While there are currently no parks, the town is developing a 2.5-acre recreational area to benefit families and attract visitors. Though the town lacks entertainment venues like movie theaters, bowling alleys, hangout spots, playgrounds, or diverse dining options, it maintains its charm as a small town so tiny you might miss it in the blink of an eye.

I live in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. Our street connects two state highways, which means we get more traffic than I'd prefer, but otherwise it's a peaceful neighborhood. There isn't much turnover in residents, so I've become familiar with most of the people who live here. People mainly occupy themselves with yard work and daily routines. In winter, we go sledding down the hill on our side street. Our house sits at the front corner of the street, allowing us to observe everyone coming and going throughout the day, and we're familiar with the vehicles that frequent our area. We tend to notice when unfamiliar vehicles appear. Some neighbors take walks for exercise or to walk their dogs, while children ride their bikes and engage in typical activities you'd expect. We spend considerable time at home since we work remotely. There are four of us - my wife and I, plus our two daughters aged eleven and fourteen. We enjoy outdoor activities, even in the rain, and occasionally barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with pleasant cooking aromas. The sound of lawnmowers is nearly constant from March through October, when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood, originally wooded, has many trees providing ample shade, though this means plenty of leaf-raking and burning in autumn. I enjoy the scent of burning leaves, which signals fall's arrival. Recently, our winters have been mild, making it feel like an extended autumn. With our garage at the rear of the house, we rarely use the front door except for occasional visitors. When I work in the garage on my truck or other projects with the doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are particularly quiet, though Thanksgiving and other celebrations like Mother's Day and Christmas bring out-of-town visitors and extra parked cars throughout the neighborhood. Overall, I enjoy living here - it would be perfect if it weren't a through street.

I live in the heart of the high desert, surrounded by endless expanses of dirt. Unless you've actually lived here, it's difficult to understand what it's like to be constantly surrounded by brown landscapes, and when you do spot a lawn, you know the owner is investing a fortune in its maintenance. When I first moved here in the 1990s, houses were far apart. While this remains largely true today, there have been many new developments. The area is becoming more urban with each passing day, though this seems to be a common trend everywhere.

The people are generally friendly, but like any city, there are better and worse areas. My neighborhood is filled with friendly elderly residents, suggesting it's one of the nicer areas. The local stores are mainly chain establishments like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For upscale shopping, you need to travel elsewhere, as we don't have stores like Whole Foods.

Construction appears to be the dominant industry here, though I'm not basing this on official statistics. This makes sense given how underdeveloped the city remains, with plenty of open space for building. This prospect concerns me, as I appreciate things as they are. Having left a big city, I'm not eager to return to that lifestyle. Speaking of construction, that's my field - I work as a drywall and T-bar installer.

What I love about my home is the wildlife. People are drawn to the high desert for various reasons, particularly its stark beauty. The high desert's climate and landscape have created unique ecosystems that require protection and host diverse wildlife. Residents should educate themselves about their non-human neighbors to ensure peaceful coexistence.

My family has adapted well to desert life. My three children are fascinated by lizards and desert insects - as I write this, they're outside trying to catch different specimens. We have several attractions here, including the San Bernardino County Fair in Victorville, which offers a unique desert experience. Nearby Wrightwood offers snow-covered mountains and winter sports opportunities. The Victor Valley Museum showcases the area's natural history, featuring geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical items that chronicle Victorville's social and industrial development.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I would say my situation is rather unique. Unlike others who might respond as homeowners with their independent lives, my circumstances are somewhat different. I consider my neighborhood to be my college campus, with my dormitory community being my primary community. I also view the broader campus area as my neighborhood, though to a lesser degree.

Despite this unconventional setup, my neighborhood shares many similarities with traditional neighborhoods. Like any typical neighborhood, mine has housing, residents, shops, and recreational areas. Let's begin by examining the "housing" in my neighborhood. There are three distinct types of accommodation in my immediate area: apartments, traditional houses, and dormitories.

The apartments typically house 2-4 people per unit, with 4-6 units per floor in two-story buildings, accommodating roughly 20 residents per building. Then there are the traditional houses, available for rent to those affiliated with the university, typically featuring 2-4 bedrooms and often occupied by alumni. However, these houses are fewer in number due to space efficiency concerns. The most common housing type is the dormitory, accommodating hundreds of students, typically with two students sharing a room.

Our community takes pride in its diversity, reflected in the varied demographic makeup. We have residents from all cultural backgrounds and age groups. Most faculty and staff occupy the traditional houses, while newer students live in dormitories and upperclassmen tend to reside in apartments.

As a self-contained community, our neighborhood features numerous amenities, including various dining options, university-branded clothing stores, and grocery shops, ensuring all essential needs are met within our boundaries. Our neighborhood park serves as a communal gathering space for our diverse population, maintained and secured through the collective effort of all community members.

In my neighborhood, sidewalks are scarce. The terrain slopes downward everywhere, and my house is perched at the peak of the steepest hill in the area. Locals refer to it as the "workout hill" since it's popular among joggers for their daily exercise. With no sidewalks on my street, pedestrians share the road with vehicles. The pavement is damaged in several spots, making driving somewhat treacherous. The utility lines around the block appear worn and tattered, largely due to frequent storms and rainfall that cause falling branches to damage power lines, resulting in numerous repairs that give them a patchwork appearance.

Towering evergreens dominate the landscape, though they're not particularly beloved by residents who often remove them to preserve their ocean views. That's why many homes are constructed high on the hillside, featuring large glass-fronted upper floors that cascade down the slope, each positioned to capture the bay's panorama. The view is particularly stunning at sunset when the water appears to glow from within and the sky takes on amber hues. However, cloud cover is common, filtering most sunlight through a misty veil. The climate is predominantly overcast and humid, allowing moss to flourish on virtually every surface - from rooftops to vehicles and handrails. I once discovered this firsthand when my car, left idle in the driveway for a month, developed a green, mossy coating that took hours to remove.

Despite having a school nearby, there aren't many children in the area. The demographic skews older, with numerous retirees. Dogs, rather than children, are the prevalent presence, often seen lounging on lawns or chasing each other along the streets. They're known to wander into homes through open doors or windows - I've personally had to escort one out of my living room. Wild rabbits are also abundant, much to gardeners' dismay as they damage plants and create burrows in lawns. My cats, however, have effectively reduced the local rabbit population. The area's bird life includes sparrows, hummingbirds, and occasional visits from hawks or eagles, though the resident crows usually drive them away.

While there are no nearby shops, a short walk downhill to the waterfront reveals several restaurants specializing in fresh seafood. Though the beach is minimal, the rocky shoreline provides entertainment for stone-throwing. The bay itself is relatively narrow, with the opposite shore visible through the mist most days.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, you'll have no trouble finding it! Public transit is readily available and remains one of New York City's most popular ways to get around. Bensonhurst maintains a distinctly urban character that makes you feel you're truly in New York City. During your visit, you'll notice Asian businesses everywhere – a result of the significant Asian population growth over the past twenty years. You'll find Asian-owned establishments on practically every block, particularly supermarkets and laundromats. These businesses are highly regarded by locals for their excellent food quality, competitive prices, and convenience. In my immediate vicinity alone, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking radius.

However, Bensonhurst isn't exclusively Asian – it's a richly diverse community of immigrants and their first and second-generation American children. While many prominent local businesses are Asian-owned, the neighborhood offers other attractions, including a newly renovated park featuring multiple basketball courts, a spacious field for soccer or baseball, handball courts, playground equipment, and a splash pad for children to enjoy in summer. True to New York City's character, the park reflects the area's diversity, with people from all backgrounds harmoniously sharing the space.

The neighborhood consists mainly of residential buildings, primarily two-family houses, with some co-ops and condominiums. While the residents are generally friendly, the area can be noisy, with cars frequently blasting music or revving engines, especially in the morning. Evening visitors should remain vigilant – while the neighborhood is relatively safe, there are occasional troublemakers, bullies, and thieves. I personally experienced bullying here years ago, and package theft remains an ongoing issue. Despite city regulations requiring pet owners to clean up after their dogs, compliance is poor, and you'll likely encounter dog waste on sidewalks during your walks to the train station or supermarket. Watch your step and keep your shoes clean!

The first thing you need to understand about Portland, Oregon is the meaning of "weird." The unofficial city motto, displayed on the back of a building that serves as a pizza restaurant, bar, music venue, and strip club - while skirting legal boundaries in at least half of these ventures - is "Keep Portland Weird." For some, this represents a nostalgic plea to remember Portland of the 1990s and early 2000s, a less famous and more affordable Portland that fostered unique and creative subcultures. For others, it serves as an inviting call - come to Portland, where being called weird is actually a compliment.

Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the endless construction of condominiums to house them, Portland maintains its peculiarity. Being weird doesn't always mean being accepting, but it does mean embracing what's typically rejected elsewhere. This doesn't mean we lack modern amenities or modern challenges. Like the rest of America, we source most of our goods from China. While there are countless ways to be weird or unconventional, Portland has its share of normalcy too. We have yoga enthusiasts, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps being weird simply means we take it all less seriously.

In my neighborhood, as in many Portland areas, you'll find colorfully painted houses, street-side gardens blooming with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and "free boxes" during summer months. These free boxes - traditionally cardboard containers but sometimes plastic bags or crates - hold items people are giving away. They possess a certain magic, surprisingly often containing perfect treasures for passing strangers. While typically filled with clothes and books, they might contain anything.

The magical possibility of discovering something while walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood embodies Portland's essence - at least to me, though I'm just one variety of weird among thousands. Some of my neighbors would never consider selecting clothes from a sidewalk box. They prefer goat yoga (yes, actual yoga with live goats) or attending Timbers matches (our soccer team). Portland brims with people passionate about various pursuits, whether actively chasing their dreams or contemplating them over one too many drinks at the bar.

Indeed, Portland faces challenges with drug abuse, which often stems from mental health issues, potentially exacerbated by our lengthy rainy season and persistent cloud cover. We also struggle with homelessness, drawing people with our relatively better social services, though like everywhere else in the country, these prove insufficient. The housed population oscillates between compassion and contempt - in this regard, we're not weird at all.

The mountains are eternally present. In the north, they witness the sun's journey every morning and every evening. No matter how much I forget about them or how consumed I am by work and life, they remain there - steadfast, unchallenged, and unmoved by life's trials. On my most stressful days, they demand attention, and when I turn to them, they provide solace to my troubled spirit, lending me strength to continue, one day at a time. I first arrived here when I began my undergraduate studies, and the mountains north of campus were what initially captivated me. While the university certainly has its own breathtaking features - buildings, ponds, and trees that hold a special place in my heart - it's the mountains that truly reign supreme. The town itself has its own unique beauty. Countless cafés have hosted many hours of caffeine-fueled study sessions. A short walk or bus ride to downtown immerses you in an atmosphere of antiquity, with weathered colored bricks adorning restaurants and office buildings. Here, this seemingly suburban town reveals as much energy and vitality as its urban neighbor. This bustling atmosphere doesn't extend far though - one can quickly retreat to the peaceful small-town atmosphere just past the library. This contrast of environments in such close proximity gives the city a magical quality, as if inviting exploration. It's easy to collect precious memories, each tied to a different part of town - from walking past rusty park swings with friends after pulling an all-nighter to rushing through the busy downtown to catch a movie at the elegant theater with university-provided tickets. Yet, like any place in life, it also harbors difficult memories. The ponds, particularly, serve both for reflection and early-morning crying sessions during existential crises - the latter being something I'm quite familiar with. While observing the turtles, ducks, and insects living their purposeful lives, I couldn't help questioning my own place in this mysterious journey called life. So I walked beyond the pond, past the park and suburban houses, until I reached a main street. As the sun cast its brilliant rays over the palm trees, painting the sky, I realized I was heading north. And there they were, as always - the imposing mountains touching the hazy blue and yellow sky, towering above any building on the horizon, and without words, they awakened in me a sense of endurance.

At first glance, you might miss it - it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, not somewhere you'd expect to find places to live. At least, not places where most people would choose to make their home. But venture behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and past the hotels that only see occasional occupancy save for summer family reunions, and you'll discover a thriving community. Within these neighborhoods, along these streets, you'll find several apartment complexes - arranged methodically like Russian nesting dolls that have been carefully disassembled and lined up along the road. The first apartments you encounter have made headlines for some questionable activities, so we'll gloss over those - appearances can be misleading, after all. But the neighboring complexes reveal an entirely different world, one that few locals even know exists. Opposite these buildings stands a community college satellite campus - a tranquil collection of buildings keeping watch over the street, where drowsy students arrive with coffee in hand at 7 AM to begin their day. Iron gates creak open to welcome them one by one, while frustrated commuters gesture and grumble about traffic delays on busy days. The road intersects with another residential street, flanked by a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for those recovering from injuries on the other. The center features welcoming porch furniture and a languid ceiling fan that stirs the heavy summer air. Children play in the park across the way, turning cartwheels across the spiky grass while bees drift between roadside flowers. Retirees walk their dogs along the path, frowning at skateboarding teenagers while politely acknowledging groups of teenage girls gathered near the playground, sharing gossip about boys and trending YouTube stars. A strip mall beside the park houses an affordable sushi restaurant that's never too crowded, a pool supply store, and a nail salon tucked between them. It's the quintessential strip mall experience - you could stock up on pool supplies, get your nails done, and enjoy hibachi chicken all at once. There's also a self-serve frozen yogurt shop where you'll often spot teenagers from the park clutching cups topped with various toppings while attempting skateboard tricks and vaping, thinking it makes them look cool. This neighborhood represents a slice of Americana - a fragment of history in the unhurried South where even time seems to stand still.

My neighborhood is fascinating. Most houses are single-family homes, though some have been divided into two units while remaining connected. My house has a small front yard and a narrow driveway on its left side. Like most others, it reminds one of a time when suburban living embodied the American dream. This dream once seemed to unite people, but is now fading. Yet my neighborhood and many others endure, still testifying that the dream lives on.

People aren't as optimistic as they once were, and the maintenance of small yards isn't what it used to be, but every driveway still holds a car or two, and children still play as if their immediate surroundings were their entire universe. The public school, standing for nearly 90 years, continues to inspire hope in today's youth while stirring memories in older residents. Churches are sparse and mostly empty, but the basketball courts remain full of life. Though each house looks different, they share a common spirit.

There's a large supermarket called "Super A," owned by a Yemeni family - possibly the only Arab family in the neighborhood. Most residents are African American. The streets are wide, with children playing football, pausing only for passing cars. Many neighbors have lived here for generations, sharing stories of times when everyone knew everyone else. A former karate school has become a pharmacy - a sign of changing times. There's also a small theater showing classic films at reduced prices, avoided by youth for its lack of new releases but cherished by older residents seeking an affordable night out.

A single expressway passes through our town, though its exits are in the neighboring community. A petition for our own exit was once denied after elders convinced the city council it would harm the town's character. Now we're building a new high school and debating a town mascot - I believe a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would perfectly capture our town's essence.

Living in a major city, my neighborhood is incredibly diverse. Residential areas are scattered seemingly randomly among commercial districts where various businesses operate. Some of these establishments consist of offices, while others are various shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There's no shortage of new dining options or shopping opportunities. While some stores are large, well-known brands owned by major corporations, small boutiques are becoming increasingly popular. These aren't just found in various shopping malls, but also line the streets, often within walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be peaceful and tranquil if not surrounded by so many points of interest.

There are several nearby parks, and I've noticed people frequently visit these with their young children. Speaking of people, there's remarkable diversity in my neighborhood. In one small area, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a group of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Extending slightly beyond my immediate neighborhood, there's even greater racial and ethnic diversity, though people often cluster into their own distinct communities within the city. We have areas known as Koreatown, Chinatown, Little Armenia, and many others, all just a few miles away. However, even a few miles can mean a lengthy journey here. A mere 10-mile trip can take up to two hours due to traffic, especially during rush hour.

Despite the proximity of various attractions, hardly anyone walks in my city. The city is vast, and people generally don't prefer to commute on foot. Consequently, we have some of the world's worst traffic congestion, and parking is challenging virtually everywhere. Ironically, there's been extensive construction in recent years, with large apartment buildings being added throughout the city. While it appears to be a popular destination, many residents are concerned about the prospect of more people moving in and additional vehicles on the roads.

Housing in my city is diverse. Not everyone lives or wants to live in large apartment buildings. Residential areas consist of houses of various sizes, smaller apartment buildings, and condominiums. Some properties are single-family homes, while others are duplexes. This variety exists even within my immediate neighborhood, offering diverse housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood comprises people of various ages, and truthfully, I'm not familiar with most of my neighbors. It's not really a close-knit community nowadays, although I have fond memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and other neighborhood friends who were around my age.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we passed the cornfields that stretched to the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, knowing she would be shocked by the vastness of the open landscape. She came from a town where the grocery store was just a 5-minute walk from her house - she had never seen such expansive space in her life. Overwhelmed by the endless cornfields, I shared my experiences of growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from. Following a two-lane country road, you'll find a water-filled quarry, and just beyond it lies the small development where I live. The houses, primarily built of brick and stucco, each sit on at least half an acre of meticulously maintained land. Spring brings an abundance of annual flowers alongside Midwestern trees that transform with each season. The driveways showcase gleaming high-end Mercedes Benz vehicles, freshly washed and sparkling in the midday sun. Along the road to my gray stucco house, my Korean neighbor can always be found outside with a welcoming smile, spending his days mowing and singing over the hum of his machine. Though he's grown older and lost some of his sharpness, this former doctor remains a beloved neighborhood character, often blending into the landscape with his John Deere Zero Turn mower. At my home, geese roam the side yard, pursued by our terrier, while a small stream flowing to the quarry creates a backdrop of natural sounds - bullfrogs, running water, and occasional moos from nearby farms. Beyond our handmade wooden bridge lies an untouched haven of natural trees, herbs, and wildflowers - my childhood playground where I built forts, chased wildlife, and found friendship with neighborhood children. The brutal winters transform our yard from lush green to stark wilderness, with formerly vibrant trees becoming bare silhouettes. Snowfall creates an overnight wonderland, complete with snow angels and snowmen crafted by my sister. Our childhood rivalries often played out in winter warfare, with elaborate snow forts housing our arsenal of snowballs. In this magical space, we lived in a world of make-believe, carefree children lost in the wonder of youth.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can’t blame just them. There are apartments across the street from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live. I can afford it, and there’s plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like how the university is within walking distance and there are two bus stops so that I can get to the store and downtown with ease.
My neighborhood is made up of duplex's on a cul-de-sac. They are intermittently placed and spaced so that they look like individual houses. The only difference is each is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, but not all, are friends with each other. We stand at the end of a not pre-decided driveway some evenings and chit chat while the small children of the neighborhood play with their toys, sidewalk chalk or fly their kites. It is very refreshing in this modern all to mechanical/computer filled world. It is rather like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees enhanced by blue skies and white billowing clouds. The only downfall? This season, we are experiencing tornado warnings and for the first time, last night we actually heard actual tornado sirens so we had to head towards shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my littlest dog along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and remained in the livingroom, nervous and barking, nervous about the odd circumstances. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail which fell all bout the ground. After the storm the road literally was steaming from the change of temperature. We went from 92 to 75 in a matter of minutes. The hail immediately melted when it hit the hot pavement. As I looked up towards the clearing skies, the sun came out and it started to rain. A double rainbow apparated. I ran into the house and grabbed my camera. Quickly snapped pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were in awe, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour, before some people finally came home from wherever they were when the thunderstorm hit. Then it was business as usual, mom’s and children outside as dinner cooked. Such a friendly neighborhood for this gal who has recently moved form NH to NC. I adore the southern accent that people speak with. I have a two bedroom and two bath apartment, as does everyone. Though all the houses look the same on the outside, not all of the apartments are the same on the inside. Some are actually quite tiny. It doesn’t make sense to me. I love to walk along the biggest field behind where I live and mosey down to the pond that is not made for swimming. I have seen deer and in the morning you can hear the giant bullfrog singing his song. It is a fantastic place to live just forty minutes outside the city of Charlotte. Each morning is welcomed by the sound of roosters crowing from the surrounding farms. It is rather like living in a small community village of it’s own. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that you can hear braying in the evening to let us know he is there. I was lucky to find this gem of a neighborhood.
Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them.
